description: The first part of the course presents alternative methods of preparing managerial accounting information, and the remainder of the course examines how these methods are used by companies. Managerial accounting is a company's internal language, and is used for decision-making, production management, product design and pricing and for motivating and evaluating employees. Unless you understand managerial accounting, you cannot have a thorough understanding of a company's internal operations. What you learn in this course will help you understand the operations of your future employer (and enable you to be more successful at your job), and help you understand other companies you encounter in your role as competitor, consultant, or investor.
name: MANAGERIAL ACCOUNTING

values.comments:
Accounting 102 is a two-part course in which the first half presents alternative methods of preparing managerial accounting information, and the remainder of the course examines how companies use these methods. Managerial accounting is a company's internal language, and is used for decision-making, production management, product design and pricing and for motivating and evaluating employees. Unless you understand managerial accounting, you cannot have a thorough understanding of a company's internal operations.  What is taught in this course will provide the students with an understanding of the operations of future employers, enable students to be more successful at their jobs, and help students understand other companies they will encounter in their role as competitor, consultant, or investor.

Students said the course was somewhat interesting.  One thought it “should not be in the core,” but most found the course well structured and effective because of the professor. Another student felt the course focused “more on economics than accounting.” 

Students found Professor Gonedes “a very fair, reasonable, and fun professor.”  Many said he was personable and always available for extra help or discussion.  He was dubbed a “cool guy” and many appreciated that he kept classes short. He spent most of the class time explaining problems, which students felt was “a very wise and pragmatic way to teach accounting.”

There were 6 quizzes that occurred every other week in order to “make sure you keep on top of the material.”  The class grade “is given directly from an average of the exams.” In order to be exempt from the final, you must get an A on all 6 exams. Many felt the best way to learn in the class was to read the book before class to ask specific questions about problems. This class is part of the Wharton core.

Accounting 102 presents alternative methods of preparing managerial accounting information in the first part of the course and the remainder of the course examines how companies use these methods. Managerial accounting is a company's internal language, and is used for decision-making, production management, product design and pricing, and for motivating and evaluating employees. Unless one understands managerial accounting, one cannot have a thorough understanding of a company's internal operations. What students learn in this course will help them understand the operations of their future employers, enabling them to be more successful at their jobs, and help them understand other companies they encounter in their role as competitor, consultant, or investor.

Many students felt that the material in this course was “useful,” although a number also noted that it was “boring.” Generally, students found the lector slides to be “helpful.”

Most students had high praise for Professor Defeo. In particular, many students highlighted how much “he truly cares about his students and goes out of his way to get to know every student and to help every student succeed.”  In particular, students noted that he was “very willing to talk” and was “very accessible.” They appreciated that he would “greet students from the class when he saw them around campus.”  Several students described Professor Defeo as “wordy and verbose,” but the majority felt that he “explained the material very clearly” and was “very thorough.” 

This course is part of the Wharton core and does not have any prerequisites.  A couple of students wished that the class included graded assignments so that final grades were based on more than exams. A few other students noted that the questions on the exams “did not always correspond to the material.”  Most students, however, did not comment on the difficulty of the course or the exams.
